awd_titl_txt: SGER:  Preliminary Assessment of Newly Discovered/Confirmed Terrestrial Low-Angle Impacts
awd_abstract_narration: Large meteorite impact craters on the Earth are rare at best, and               only Tunguska in Siberia is known to be less than 10,000 years                  old.  However, there is strong evidence that a large meteorite                  (est. over 100 meters in diameter) struck in South America                      (Argentina) in the very recent past, possibly within the last                   2000 years.  At present this crater is virtually unknown to both                the public and the scientific community but knowledge of it's                   existence is bound to spread rapidly.  If this impact was caused                by a bolide bigger than Tunguska and the crater is better                       preserved than Meteor Crater, the scientific implications will be               startling.  This award will enable the PI to visit the site this                Fall where he and his local collaborators plan to conduct field                 investigations, collect samples and do some preliminary analysis.
